support.description: Content is actively maintained. Please report errors and inconsistencies

author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
segments.en: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape

segments.pli: Avusitaṃ tena brahmacariyaṃ, ārakā so imasmā dhammavinayā”ti.
segments.en: has not completed the spiritual journey and is far from this teaching and training.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāmī”ti.
segments.en: For I don’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and liable to fall apart, is it fit to be regarded thus:
‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, sotasmimpi nibbindati, ghānasmimpi nibbindati, jivhāyapi nibbindati, kāyasmimpi nibbindati, manasmimpi nibbindati.
segments.en: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

segments.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
segments.en: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

segments.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

sections.title: “Mendicants, anyone who doesn’t truly understand the six fields…

suttaplex.blurb: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.
